B003Q6D29Q|5.0|First of all, I haven't read the 2005 novel by Kazuo Ishigiro that this film is based on, nor did I know much of anything about it apart from the basics (dystopian English alternate-world story) before seeing the film. So the few problems I mention or areas that I feel the film is deficient in dealing with are wholly a product of my experience with the movie - I suspect that some of these issues might be less problematic in the novel.  As you can see from my rating and review, I think the positives far outweigh the negatives.<br /><br />Second of all, if you know even less than I did, be prepared for **SPOILERS**<br /><br />All that out of the way, what we have here is a story taking place in a roughly contemporary (1978-94) England, a country (and presumably, world) radically changed by medical advances that did not happen in our world. Or...maybe. The most fascinating element of this film to me, and I'm sure the most infuriating to many viewers, is that we never get a really clear picture as to just what the technology is, how things have changed. The focus here is not on technology, on the science fictional aspects, on gadgetry or medicine. We get a few references to cloning, but never any details; we learn fairly quickly that the children we're introduced to at the Hailsham boarding school have a \\"special\\" destiny, and the film follows three of them in particular, one of whom, Kathy (Izzy Meikle-Small as a child/Carey Mulligan as an adult) narrates the film from 1994 at around the age of 30.<br /><br />Kathy, her companions Tommy (Charlie Rowe/Andrew Garfield) and Ruth (Ella Purnell/Keira Knightley) are all being raised in a comfortable, serene - almost idyllic - countryside school to face a very particular and peculiar destiny. We get several hints early on - but only get the full heartbreaking story from a sympathetic (and summarily dismissed) young teacher named Lucy (Sally Hawkins): the children are all clones who will be harvested for their organs before the age of 30, dying typically after their third or fourth \\"donation\\". Lucy delivers the news with compassion and sadness; the rest of society, including the leaders of the school and apparently virtually all donors, have simply accepted this new world order, for the sake of the longer lives (we're told in a brief script at the beginning of the film that the average lifespan has passed 100) and comfort it has given them. The donors are essentially regarded as cattle.  Eventually they move on from the school to \\"The Cottages\\" a few years later in the second third of the film, as the forward and vivacious Ruth has taken up with the awkward and introverted Tommy, which Kathy considered becoming a \\"Carer\\", helping to take care of the donors before she herself becomes one.  In the last third of the film, 1994, all three confront their inevitable destinies.<br /><br />In most such visions, the story would be about attempts to escape the repressive regime, or overthrow it. The genius and heartbreak of NEVER LET ME GO is that it shows a society - or a very tiny portion of one - that is completely conditioned to the way things are now; nobody even dreams of running away or changing things, and the idea of there being an ethical dilemma is never actually broached by any character until quite near the end of the film. This was, I'll admit, something of a problem for me as I was watching the film - it's really quite hard to take the blind acceptance of such an awful fate on the part of everyone; but I think that Ishiguro and the filmmakers here are making a statement that only seems unrealistic if we forget the history of the last century. I do have a slight problem with the notion that things could have happened so very quickly in a democracy like England, but if we look at something like Orwell's \\"1984\\" - set 35 years after its publication - as a model, we shouldn't be surprised. The English dystopian vision has always seemed a particularly mordant and immediate one. And setting the film in essentially our time also allows it to be made much more cheaply - it's \\"science fiction\\" certainly, but it doesn't require the kinds of sets and effects that we usually think of the genre as having nowadays.<br /><br />I think that another factor that is going to be problematic for many is that we just see a very small fraction of this society, which must be so very different in many aspects but which looks essentially the same to we viewers. We are kept in the presence of our three main characters throughout, and we never see the recipients of any of these peoples' \\"gifts\\"; we never encounter the government; we never hear anyone from outside of their little world express an opinion. For me this helped keep the exquisite sadness and intensity of the growing sense of loss that these young people had fresh and vivid throughout, and without encumbering the actual film with external voices, we are allowed to consider all the ethical ramifications and meanings of this changed world entirely on our own. The donors could be read as metaphors for slavery; for how we treat animals; for abortion; for the place of women in a man's world; in short, for any way in which the rulers and the majority of a society have treated and continue to treat those without any power. There are several moments where the word \\"soul\\" is used - though the film has no visible religious agenda, the notion is that the idea of living organ donation is perhaps accepted because the clones are viewed as not having souls, as not being fully human - an argument that was made not so long ago about other kinds of people in the world we live in.<br /><br />The acting and nearly everything about the production is pretty impressive; director Romanek has just made two previous features, ONE HOUR PHOTO and STATIC, over the past 15 years.  I haven't seen either of those, but he has a sure hand here, putting together Alex Garland's screenplay and the performances of the fine ensemble with a minimum of sentimentality or lingering, overt emotion - which if anything serves to increase the power of the storytelling and the ultimate tragedy of the piece. Rachel Portman's music is very low-key, repetetive, insistent; at first it irritated me a bit, but gradually it grew on me, mirroring the ultimately dead-end, resigned lives of the protaganists. Of the cast I have to single out Carey Mulligan, who seems likely to get some of the same kind of awards talk she did a year ago when she burst on the scene in An Education. She has to communicate a calmness, empathy, resignation and yet a flicker of never-ending internal determination and purpose throughout the film, and I don't know that many actresses could have managed.<br /><br />As Orson Welles once said about [[ASIN:B002XUL6SA Make Way for Tomorrow]], another heartbreaker about the inevitability of fate, it would make a stone cry.  One of the best of 2010 - don't miss it.me also allows it to be made much more cheaply - it's \\"science fiction\\" certainly, but it doesn't require the kinds of sets and effects that we usually think of the genre as having nowadays.    I think that another factor that is going to be problematic for many is that we just see a very small fraction of this society, which must be so very different in many aspects but which looks essentially the same to we viewers. We are kept in the presence of our three main characters throughout, and we never see the recipients of any of these peoples' \\"gifts\\"; we never encounter the government; we never hear anyone from outside of their little world express an opinion. For me this helped keep the exquisite sadness and intensity of the growing sense of loss that these young people had fresh and vivid throughout, and without encumbering the actual film with external voices, we are allowed to consider all the ethical ramifications and meanings of this changed world entirely on our own. The donors could be read as metaphors for slavery; for how we treat animals; for abortion; for the place of women in a man's world; in short, for any way in which the rulers and the majority of a society have treated and continue to treat those without any power. There are several moments where the word \\"soul\\" is used - though the film has no visible religious agenda, the notion is that the idea of living organ donation is perhaps accepted because the clones are viewed as not having souls, as not being fully human - an argument that was made not so long ago about other kinds of people in the world we live in.    The acting and nearly everything about the production is pretty impressive; director Romanek has just made two previous features, ONE HOUR PHOTO and STATIC, over the past 15 years.  I haven't seen either of those, but he has a sure hand here, putting together Alex Garland's screenplay and the performances of the fine ensemble with a minimum of sentimentality or lingering, overt emotion - which if anything serves to increase the power of the storytelling and the ultimate tragedy of the piece. Rachel Portman's music is very low-key, repetetive, insistent; at first it irritated me a bit, but gradually it grew on me, mirroring the ultimately dead-end, resigned lives of the protaganists. Of the cast I have to single out Carey Mulligan, who seems likely to get some of the same kind of awards talk she did a year ago when she burst on the scene in An Education. She has to communicate a calmness, empathy, resignation and yet a flicker of never-ending internal determination and purpose throughout the film, and I don't know that many actresses could have managed.    As Orson Welles once said about [[ASIN:B002XUL6SA Make Way for Tomorrow]], another heartbreaker about the inevitability of fate, it would make a stone cry.  One of the best of 2010 - don't miss it.
0385342047|2.0|I have read all of Sophie Kinsella's books, and have enjoyed the way she tells a story.   Unfortunately, Mini Shopaholic seemed to have been written in a hurry and lacked all the fun and irony of her previous books.  I kept thinking that something funny or meaningful was going to happen as I turned the pages, but nothing ever did.   It was just 400 pages of Becky planning a surprise party for her husband with a few mentions about her toddler's bad behavior, her job as a personal shopper, and her shopping addiction.   The title and beginning of the book makes one believe that there will be some development of the newest Brandon character, Minnie, and her relationship with Becky.  That didn't happen in the book, other than the description of a few of Minnie's temper tantrums, none of which Becky could control, and a brief encounter with a nanny whose assessment results in saying that Minnie has no issues, but that Becky needs help for her shopping addiction.   Everything in the book seemed ridiculous including the fact that 2 year-old, highly intelligent Minnie could only speak a maximum of 2 grammatically incorrect words at a time (such as \\"Mine book\\").     I don't understand what Sophie Kinsella was trying to accomplish with this book.  The only interesting relationship discussed was that of Luke and his birth mother, but the reader is left hanging in terms of what happened in the past that caused their communication to cease, and why Elinor is different (older, more sensitive) from the way she was in the past.  Sophie briefly mentions Becky's sister, Jess, and could have done more to show how Jess has changed and how the sisters' relationship has changed now that she is married and living next door.  Luke, who was a strong character in past books, is made to seem clueless and shallow in this book.   None of the previously likeable characters in the Shopaholic series was likeable in this book.  Minnie is a brat and the only realistic aspect of the book was at the beginning where Luke says he doesn't want another child because of the way Minnie is and that they need help to figure out why she is out of control.    Another issue with this book is that there is too much over-the-top, wasting of money, on the ridiculous party which was the plot of the entire book.  Throughout the book, although there is mention of how bad the economic times are, it doesn't seem to have affected Becky's expectations in terms of her own living standards and spending habits.      I assume that in the future, Sophie will develop Minnie's character.  I hope she doesn't make Minnie a clone of Becky.  I hope that there will be some substance in terms of the mother-daughter relationship.    This book was disappointing and I do not recommend buying it.

B0010ZR160|5.0|This movie presents us with an honest, responsible person having to make a very bad choice.<br />The choice is between \\"A\\" and \\"B\\", where \\"A\\" is also the default choice. Choosing either way will have bad consequences: the chooser is aware of this. He also knows that there is nothing to be gained by shrugging the whole thing off: choosing not to choose is the same as choosing \\"A\\".<br />This is what is properly known as a \\"dilemma\\".<br />It is also a moral dilemma such as it is rarely encountered in movies. This film is not only very well made and acted, but it has a moral depth that transcends entertainment. It is a lesson on the equivocal, slippery nature of life.<br />The setting is a rough working-class neighborhood in South Boston. It is a place where, in normal conversation, the \\"f\\" word and its various derivatives pop up after just about every other word. There are lots of drugs and crime. This is shown mostly in a low-key, but relentless, unflinching way.<br />In younger days, as a poor student renting cheap quarters, I did live in a neighborhood somewhat like that, although there was less crime - at least free-floating, disorganized crime -- and less drugs. So: not as dark and harsh as that in the movie, but close enough to compare for realism. My opinion: this movie has realism in spades.<br />The end is tragic in the classic sense: a good person is brought low, and into a kind of personal hell, by capricious fate and the limitations of human nature.<br />It is a morality play of sorts, but the lesson is given very matter of fact, without high-minded words and cheap \\"poetic\\" gestures.<br />This film makes you think, and keeps you thinking long after the last credits fade and the lights come back on.

1935251740|3.0|A large part of 'Biocentrism' is spent exploring the Copenhagen interpretation while completely ignoring the opposite viewpoint. The book makes a good case for bio-participatism. However it fails to succeed in arguing the case that reality is centric to consciousness or biological beingness. This tunnel vision is remarkably similar to the mechanistic philosophy of modern day science in that it assumes things can only be one way and not also the other.<br /><br />I look forward to the day when both mechanical and transcendental aspects of reality can exist side-by-side the same way irrational numbers sit adjacent to rational ones on the number line. Reality as composed of both physical mechanisms and intangible conscious meanderings is a potpourri of natural, imaginary, real, complex, and every other form of abstraction imagined or unimagined. In no way should a theory of everything be boxed or shoe-horned to fit into one idea just so we can pat ourselves on the back and in an illusory way conclude \\"all things are explained!\\"<br /><br />Even though the writing style was extremely approachable and the personal elements humanizing. I found Dr. Lanza's finger pointing and general condemnation of broad categories of scientific research as self serving and hypocritical. This really came to the fore on pg. 175 when he wrote,<br /><br />  '\\"Let man,\\" declared Emerson, \\"then learn the revelation of all nature and all thought to his heart; this, namely; that the Highest dwells with him; that the sources of nature are in his own mind.\\"<br /><br />  If only the physicists had respected the limits of their science as Skinner did his.\\"'<br /><br />Dr. Lanza is as guilty of this as any physicist when he claims the building blocks of biology or consciousness have any bearing on inert physical structures. Achieving a physical theory of everything would likely provide some insight into consciousness. However like an EEG we'd probably have no real picture of what quantum-states or brain-waves are telling us about what's going on in a persons conscious subjective mind. Similarly understanding consciousness down to its roots would probably tell us something about physical reality, but more than likely we can expect that it would have little to say about quantum gravity. Blurring the lines to say one tells us wholly about the other and vice versa is the height of sophistic thinking.<br /><br />While it's fun to think, \\"Reality is a function of my conscious existence.\\" The evidence is still very much inconclusive any way you look at it.

0312600844|5.0|It is encouraging, I guess, that the five star reviews are running slightly ahead of the one star reviews.  I hope potential readers won't be put off by negative reviews at this site that complain about: \\"disgusting\\" sex scenes (of the 560 pages, there might be a total of 3 that describe a sex act, and the descriptions are quite tame by modern standards); Freedom being a rewrite of [[ASIN:0312421273 The Corrections]] (similar only in that both are about dysfunctional families; one might as well complain that Updike kept rewriting [[ASIN:0449911659 Rabbit, Run]] in his [[ASIN:0679444599 subsequent chronicles]] of Rabbit Angstrom's life); unlikeable characters (the main characters are believable, multi-faceted, and troubled; just like real people, they are likable in their best moments, not so likable in their worst); the \\"boring\\" plot (if the realistic, intense drama of human interaction bores you, then yes, you might be better off reading a fantasy or a thriller); the glorification of \\"liberal\\" politics (a main character, Joey, is an unabashed conservative, yet he's quite a sympathetic figure by the novel's end, while liberal Walter comes across as politically naive through much of the novel); or chapters that are too long (a problem easily solved with a book mark).  Given that a shocking number of one star reviewers give no reason for their rating beyond \\"hated it\\" or \\"worst book ever,\\" I have to wonder how many of them even read it.  If you're thinking about buying this book, please don't give any weight to the one-line one star reviews.<br /><br />Freedom is a splendid novel about characters who can't help hurting each other--a common feature in even the best of families.  At times it is grim, but ultimately it's uplifting:  the characters struggle to overcome their self-imposed limitations and their pain and to become better, fuller individuals.  The sad aspects of the story are balanced by humor, while the negativity found in each of the main characters is balanced by a capacity for personal growth.  The novel is filled with moral lessons for those who are open to them.  Chief among these is the need to find a way to be better to those we love, to understand and appreciate them, and to be more forgiving of ourselves.  Freedom illustrates that there is no magic formula for becoming a better or happier person; the characters each explore their own paths, sometimes faltering, sometimes failing.  None of them are perfect ... but who is?  The point is:  they try.<br /><br />Franzen writes with elegance and sureness and subtlety.  This is one of the best American novels I've read in years.  Five stars from me ... big, fat, spangled stars for a brilliant, lively novel.a capacity for personal growth.  The novel is filled with moral lessons for those who are open to them.  Chief among these is the need to find a way to be better to those we love, to understand and appreciate them, and to be more forgiving of ourselves.  Freedom illustrates that there is no magic formula for becoming a better or happier person; the characters each explore their own paths, sometimes faltering, sometimes failing.  None of them are perfect ... but who is?  The point is:  they try.    Franzen writes with elegance and sureness and subtlety.  This is one of the best American novels I've read in years.  Five stars from me ... big, fat, spangled stars for a brilliant, lively novel.

Jin's mother led a cryo reform movement until she was declared incompetent and frozen.  Living amidst the impoverish masses, Jin runs a cline for the poor. Vorkosigan finally connects the dots only leading to greater peril; by those who do not want to come in from the cold.  Simply put, Cryoburn is a timely super entry as the Imperial Auditor uncovers the stunning truth and he also learns Diplomatic Immunity will not keep him alive.<br /><br />Harriet Klausner

B003Q6D25K|3.0|Paranormal Activity 2 (Tod Williams, 2010)<br /><br />I started watching horror films in 1974, at the tender age of six, with The Exorcist. That one left with me with nothing but a raging crush on Linda Blair (that still burns thirty-six years later, by the by). And any other movie you can think of that got trumpeted \\"scariest movie EVAR!\\" by some critic or other pretty much left me the same way, either wanting to see it again because it's just awesome or wondering what all the fuss was about. In the intervening time, I've seen hundreds of horror movies. Maybe over a thousand. Of them, there have been four that, after the first seeing of them, I have absolutely refused to spend any time in a dark room. The first was Larry Hagman's 1972 Beware! The Blob, and in my defense, I was eight years old. (Can't remember completely, but I think it was the scene in the barbershop that traumatized me.) Second came Pet Sematary, my junior year in college (the sister did it, absolutely). The third was Candyman (it's the sound mix in the first meeting between Virginia Madsen and Tony Todd, which means if you haven't seen it on the big screen, you've no idea what I'm talking about). And the fourth, and I can't tell you what did it without insane amounts of spoilers, was Paranormal Activity 2.<br /><br />The worst part is, it's not all that good a movie, really. If we learned one thing from the original Paranormal Activity, a movie I was very impressed with, it's that Oren Peli is a master of blocking shots. If we learn one thing from Paranormal Activity 2, it's that Tod Williams (The Adventures of Sebastian Cole) does one hell of an Oren Peli impersonation. But every time he tries to revise and extend the convention of the original (and to be fair, he only does that once), he turns to the language of another film. (Or, to put that in not so kind a tone, the climax here is a complete rip-off of the climax of Jaume Balaguero's superior [REC].) I walked out of the theater thinking \\"meh\\" and figuring I'd give it three stars for being watchable and having a few really good jumps, but not being anything at all original. And then I got in the car and started home, and the impact of the movie started to creep in, and by the time I'd finished the seven- or eight-minute drive, I was gibbering and cowering in the corner and crying for my mommy like a schoolgirl. And that has not a blessed thing to do with Tod Williams, or almost anyone else involved in this picture; it has to do with a guy whose name you probably don't know, Michael Perry. But more on that in a minute.<br /><br />Plot: this is a prequel of sorts to the original Paranormal Activity, which allowed the team to bring back Katie and Micah, the beautiful couple from the first film. (Yes, guys, Katie Featherston is still that hot.) They are marginal characters, however. The film actually centers around Katie's sister Kristi (I should've jotted down names, because IMDB isn't listing anyone but Katie Featherston as I write this), her husband Dan, Kristi's stepdaughter Ali, and Dan and Kristi's son Hunter, who begins the film as a newborn, but is about a year old when the bulk of the action takes place. If you've seen the original, you know exactly how this is going to block out; you're going to be bored off your skull for the first half of the film with home movies. (To be fair, Williams does start the minor things happening pretty quick, but nothing that will make you jump until much later.) At one point, they come home and find the house trashed, so they have a security company come in and put up hidden cameras in the house. You know what's coming from there; you've seen the original, and Williams does nothing until the last ten minutes of the film to differentiate it from its older brother.<br /><br />Those last ten minutes are all down to Michael Perry, who's written for such disparate, but excellent, TV shows as House, Millennium, and FreakyLinks. He does just about everything that makes mehate a sequel if I know it coming in, but he somehow manages to do it all correctly. First and most importantly, he took a two-person film (and anyone who knows me will tell you I'm a sucker for a two-person film) and made it into a family gig. I figured that was strike one before I even walked into the theater, but I have a friend who has both a German Shepherd and a toddler who steadfastly refuses to see this movie because it contains a German Shepherd and a toddler. I admit, I was one of those poking fun at her, since she's as much a horror fan as I am. But Perry knows how to mash your buttons like a caffeinated twelve-year-old playing Super Mario World, and I totally get it now, even though I have never owned a German Shepherd and haven't had a toddler in well over a decade. You add a kid and you add an animal and while you're taking the easy road to scaring the bejesus out of your audience, you're taking the effective road.<br /><br />Second, there's the whole \\"there was no explanation for the bad stuff in the first movie\\" syndrome. Scary things are scarier, in general, when you have no freakin' clue why they're even happening. As a side note, it also avoids those messy plot holes. (Combine those two things and that's what makes Ils such a better movie than Haute Tension, for example.) I figured it was inevitable that Perry would do the \\"let's explain the events of both movies here!\\" thing, and so I wasn't surprised when he did. And it's not even all that original an explanation, but it's simple, it's effective, and it does explain both movies perfectly... especially when you get to those last ten minutes.<br /><br />Which brings me to point #3. It depends on which version of the original film you saw (I have seen two, and have been told at least one more exists) and how you interpreted the events in the final scene if you saw the correct (read: original) ending. If you thought you were seeing what I thought I was seeing (most of the action took place off-camera, as you'll recall), then I can't figure out a way that the last ten minutes of this movie don't break canon. I've been trying to make it work in my head ever since I saw the movie. I'll have to go back and re-watch the end of the first one tonight to see if I missed something, but as far as I can tell, there's a canon fracture here... and I didn't care, which astounds me more than anything else about this movie. It didn't. matter. one. bit. It's cheap and it's loose and it's so obviously tacked on for convenience's sake (like a number of other pieces of the script) and it doesn't matter because it's like getting hit smack in the forehead with a piledriver. And yes, when you're sitting in a brightly-lit cafe with your pals, you will deconstruct this ending and you will, rightly, tear it to shreds, as you will for most of the movie. But the fact that it's not well-conceived does not in any way mean it is not well-executed. While trying not to give anything away, I will risk a possible slight spoiler and say that the entire reason this ending works is the ambiguity of it. It's obvious that Perry knows exactly what he's doing by making this ending ambiguous. I think had he shown what happens in the conclusion to which you are obviously being led, it wouldn't have had nearly the effect that it did. Instead, he just lets it hang there and lets your imagination do the work. That's some sort of demented genius, though I'm not sure what yet.<br /><br />While unsuccessfully searching for cast information for this flick (and Katie Featherston fetishists take note that the actress who plays Kristi really could be her sister, just shorter hair and a bit perkier of a personality), I stumbled across a story where Peli is interviewed, along with Featherston and Sloat. In it, Sloat comments, \\"When you can't really see what's going on, your imagination starts to run wild. And the truth is that anything you can imagine is going to be better than anything you can actually see.\\" That's it, exactly, it's why this works (and where it stumbles in certain places when Williams crosses the line between \\"showing just enough\\" and \\"maybe showing just a little bit too much and giving the game away\\"). Peli says \\"It taps into people's primal fears of what happens at night and while you're asleep and most vulnerable.\\" And I have yet to see if my second night post-Paranormal Activity 2 will let me shut off a light.<br /><br />I have no idea how to rate this film. It's derivative, it's not especially well-made, it takes no risks, and the downside of putting more than two actors in a movie is that you run the risk of getting some who just aren't all that great at acting. But I cannot deny that, quite simply, this movie scared the living hell out of me more than any movie I've seen in the past eighteen years. It's base, it's manipulative, but it's brutally effective. As outright ludicrous as the comparison is, perhaps you should think of it as the thinking man's I Spit on Your Grave; it's just as manipulative and exploitative, but it relies on atmosphere instead of all those messy bits. So given how conflicted I am (and given how I want to get this out before the first showing on the east coast, which I think is in about an hour and a half as I write this), I'm going to give it the gentleman's C and let you decide. ***<br /><br />Oh, one other thing, and I can't believe I didn't say it it's so obvious: do not see this without seeing the first one. The final portion of the film will make basically no sense without it, and it contains THE major spoiler for Paranormal Activity. (See the first one with the original ending, if you can; I think the original ending may be on Youtube.)way that the last ten minutes of this movie don't break canon. B003JQLJVG|4.0|Robert Plant has never been a man to rest on past laurels. He certainly doesn't need to produce new output for commercial reasons, as he could have retired for life before age 30 on the proceeds of his 12 enormously successful years as front-man for Led Zeppelin and co-songwriter (with Jimmy Page) of most of that band's most memorable numbers. However Plant has never been in the business just for the money: he has a love of performing, of recording, and of the musical material.<br /><br />\\"Band of Joy\\" was the name of the Birmingham-based, pre-Zeppelin band to which Plant and (the late) John Bonham belonged prior to them joining Page & Jones to form Led Zep in 1968. This album is however no nostalgic 1960s retrospective, though it does update and re-interpret many older American folk songs from earlier decades, a genre for which Plant holds a life-long interest and passion.<br /><br />This inevitably leads to the collection of songs on \\"Band of Joy\\" to be compared with the Grammy-winning Alison Kraus collaboration \\"Raising Sand\\" and although there are some similarities, this album is different. Some of the numbers do really stand out: a superb re-working of Richard Thompson's \\"House of Cards,\\" Crume & Kelly's \\"Falling in Love Again\\" with its very early 1950s jukebox feel, and \\"Satan Your Kingdom Must Come Down\\" linger in the memory. Only time will tell if any of these recordings slowly emerge as minor classics. What is obvious after a few listenings, however, is how this collection of songs hangs together as a whole. Despite the age of some of the original material, it sounds simultaneously contemporary but with a period feel (Dylan's \\"Modern Times\\" or even the 1990 \\"Notting Hillbillies\\" comes to mind).<br /><br />Plant's much-matured voice is pleasing on the ear and the range and passion evident for a man in his 60s continues to impress. The ensemble playing from mainly Nashville-based musicians is near-perfect: professional, crisp, faultless, at times magical, and the supporting vocals of Patty Griffin fit the material particularly well. The CD is nicely presented with its red-and-grey theme colours and all lyrics to the songs helpfully printed in full (but of course you won't get this with a download). Give it a listen.als of Patty Griffin fit the material particularly well. The CD is nicely presented with its red-and-grey theme colours and all lyrics to the songs helpfully printed in full (but of course you won't get this with a download). Give it a listen.

B003KGBISY|5.0|THE FILM    What does one say about Shichinin no Samurai?  For me it is the greatest film ever made.  Friendship, class warfare, romance, battle and a slice of life - Kurosawa packed this one dense.  We reap the rewards of the master at the top of his game. Seven Samurai is an aural, emotional journey into Japanese history and human nature.   Though there is an endless cast, each part comes through as memorable, a credit not only to Kurosawa's direction and editing, but the thoughtful performances of the actors.      There is no glory here.  In the end, this is a profound story of survival.  Stray bullets cut down the bravest and the strongest just when victory seems secure.  The ones left standing, in the end, are not heroes.  They are just lucky to be alive.      THE BLU-RAY    Having shot Hasselblad for many years, the square frame feels natural to me, even on my Sony Bravia.   Asakazu Nakai and Kurosawa's calculated photography brings us the story in a strong graphic way.  This is an intimate story that comes through in the Blu-Ray more so than the older releases.  I wouldn't say it is a huge leap, but details, including the celluloid degradation, are accurately captured.  Any softness I could spot, I would attribute to the limitations of the glass in the lenses Nakai was shooting with at the time.    Grain and reticulation in the emulsion look accurate and don't appear to have been tampered with with any sort of noise reduction.  And if there has been some digital tuning, it appears to be almost invisible.  There are plenty of scratch marks on the print but naturally, this is a hard thing to avoid for such an old film.    I have owned every release and I've already given the other ones away.  This Blu-Ray isn't on par with a modern technical marvel such as The Dark Knight.  But it is a faithful representation of the masterpiece I love.  You'll never see it better.

B003W16T9K|3.0|DG's bargain reissue of Abbado's Schubert symphony cycle is welcome, if only because it undermines the absurd price (almost $150 at the top) being asked on the used market for the original set.  When this cycle was issued in 1989, the Gramophone bent over backwards to support the Chamber Orch. of Europe, an offspring of the European Community Youth Orch. Abbado showed faith in his young musicians by recording with them instead of, say, the Vienna Phil., and on several grounds he was right. The smallish ensemble feels right for Schubert's youthful scores; Karajan's set with the Berlin Phil. feels at times like breaking a butterfly on a wheel (does anyone quote Alexander Pope anymore?), and the level of execution is satisfying, if not brilliant.<br /><br />At the same time, however, the Gramophone reviewer repeats a truism: Abbado has never shown himself to be strong in the Viennese classics, tending toward a cool slickness.  In the case of his Schubert, perhaps it's appealing to hear the music elegantly glossed over.  In the early symphonies Abbado finds a flowing pace for the lyrical slow movements, nicely balanced with vigorous, alert, light-footed Scherzos. It's amazing that we are spoiled when choosing among recordings of Sy. #1 and #2. In the days when Beecham was almost the only conductor who championed early Schubert, and he began with Sym. #3 (as I remember, Beecham only performed the first two symphonies and Sym. #4 a scant handful of times and sometimes once). Abbado's readings have lots of charm but not the substance of Harnoncourt, who aims to make even the earliest Schubert symphonic writing sound like Beethoven. Abbado takes us into the light, sparkling world of Mendelssohn, where many listeners are happy to be.<br /><br />These general comments carry us through Sym. 1-6, which all receive the same agreeable, refreshing treatment.  the only minor-key symphony, No. 4 in C minor, draws many conductors into a darker mood, and to some extent Abbado follows.  The Adagio introduction to the first movement of this work, subtitled \\"the Tragic,\\" has power, but it leads into a generically played Allegro without any weight.  the slow movement comes back with a touching poignancy, but then there's a relapse into the Scherzo, where Abbado flattens out the off-kilter syncopation instead of taking advantage of it. So it goes form work to work. As nicely done as they are, few rise to the level of best in class -- remembering that we have complete sets from Kertesz, Colin Davis, and Karajan among top conductors and good if lesser ones (in my view) from Wand, Bohm, and Jonathan Nott.<br /><br />Ultimately no Schubert cycle is worth the purchase without an outstanding no. 8 \\"Unfinished\\" and no. 9 \\"Great\\" to cap it off. Unfortunately, Abbado's \\"Unfinished\\" is one of the most uninvolved I can think of, moving in pedestrian fashion through glorious music that apparently doesn't touch him, or us. As for the Ninth, it comes off better, but to be frank, this symphony has tremendous amplitude and works best with a large orchestra. Abbado gives one of those good-enough performances that don't stick in the mind. One longs for more point and vigor, and above all for a point of view. The strings of the COI, not its strongest section, have to scramble a bit in the scurrying finale. I should also mention that DG's late-80s digital sound tends to be wiry on top when the violins play with force or in their highest register.<br /><br />Although it comes on five CDs instead of the four that Karajan and Kertesz take, Abbado's set can't be faulted for stinginess. He gives us an orchestrated version of the great four-hand piano Grand Duo in C and the overture from Rosamunde. The Grand Duo is more than a curiosity, but as it tends to happen when transcriptions try to give us a \\"new\\" symphony, you notice instead hos unsymphonic the writing is.<br /><br />In the end, it's the Kertesz set on four CDs that I'd choose for a bargain and the Harnoncourt, alsoon four CDs, for the great Concertgebouw and the conductor's bold ideas.ouw and the conductor's bold ideas.
B002ZCY7PU|5.0|All round great and entertaining DVD.    Best season so far from Chuck
B003XKPPOU|5.0|Toy Story 3 is amazing. Don't wait another day if you missed it in the theater.  Great from start to finish. Sad to see it all end, but the end was perfect!  Another Pixar masterpiece!!!
B003E7EXT0|5.0|I never tire of this story. Give me a romance based on humility any day!<br /><br />Rather than review Pride and Prejudice or Jane Austen, I would like to compliment Bethany House Publishers on the margin notes in this Insight Edition. The editors supplemented this beloved classic with notes on historical and cultural details, facts from Austen's life that parallel or illuminate the novel, modern (including films) references, tips for love, themes of faith, comments on the characters and plot, and \\"parts of the novel that just make us smile.\\"
0743454537|5.0|My Sister's Keeper is a complex, heart-wrenching story. Anna Fitzgerald was engineered so her sister, Kate, would have a better chance of living through a rare form of leukemia. Kate's cancer has come out of remission and her kidneys have given out, so Anna is expected to donate one of her kidneys. Anna then decides to sue her parents for the rights to her own body. Her unexpected decision shakes her family's foundation to its core and leads them to battle it out in court.    I really love this book. I have read it twice and both times, I finished it in a day. The voices of each character is so real and compelling, thanks to each main character having their own narrative and script to match. It really sets this book apart. I may not agree with each character's actions and decisions, but their motivations show that they come from an understandable, good place. This is true from confused, innocent Anna to her juvenile delinquent brother. I like that in this novel, there are no real bad guys or good guys or a clear defining of what is right and wrong. On one hand, Anna shouldn't have to donate a kidney if she is unwilling, after being poked and prodded for other donations since birth. On the other hand, Anna's mom, Sara, wants to make sure that Kate lives as long as she possibly can. Both sides are valid, but which one overrules the other? Jodi Picoult takes a controversial subject and adds humanity to it.    The ending of this book is amazing, unlike the film adaptation. I'm not going to spoil it for anyone, but you really won't see it coming. I broke down crying when I read it and I bet you will too. I highly recommend this book.
B002S0OBMS|1.0|It's clear that Mr Webber has indeed gone off the deep end. Using the book \\"Phantom in Manhattan\\" as the basis for this production, Mr. Webber creates a score that more resembles Jesus Christ Superstar than the classical sounds of the original Phantom. Ramin Karimloo delivers as the Phantom, but Sierra Boggess (whom also played Christine in the Las Vegas production of Phantom and Ariel in the Little Mermaid on Broadway) continues to do what she seems to do so well: disappoint. I had my reservations about this production but kept an open mind and after listening to the soundtrack/seeing the production in London, I can honestly say that this musical should have never been made. Why spoil a good thing? The characters have changed completely and not one element of this production stays true to Phantom. Therefore, we can hardly consider it a sequel. To those who are ardent fans of Phantom (and who have an ear for good singing), don't waste your time with this one.
0199537151|5.0|Victor Frankenstein was a precocious child, inspired by and obsessed with the scientists of the past. In university, he continues his obsession, which culminates in the creation of a man made of corpses. As the creature awakens, Victor is horrified and disgusted and runs away. He becomes stricken with illness shortly afterwards and his childhood friend, Henry Clerval, helps nurse him back to health. After four months, Victor finally recovers, only to find that his little brother, William, has been murdered. Sure that the fiend he created is responsible, Victor returns to his home. The tormented creature eventually reveals himself to his furious creator and relays the events leading to William's murder. After his heart-rending story, he begs his creator to make a woman for him who will accept him and become his mate. Victor agrees, but has second thoughts. Should he create another monster like the one already in existence? If he decides against this second blasphemy, what repercussions will he and his family have to endure?<br /><br />Mary Shelley's classic novel Frankenstein is an iconic work that has spawned countless spin-offs, sequels, remakes, copies, and re-imaginings. It's hardly surprising considering the eloquence and skill that she exhibits. With all the allusions and references to literature and works of science, she shows her vast education, which is even surprising today for an eighteen year old. I absolutely love this book, but I used to hate it. I remember reading it as a child and finding it boring and hard to understand. As an adult, I see the different philosophies being illustrated and the significance of its place in the romantic era. It explores themes such as the nature of man, the effect of isolation verses society on man, and the ethics of science. These are themes that science fiction authors are still writing about today, as seen in the film Splice, Scott Sigler's novel Ancestor, and countless others. This is really the epitome of the gothic novel, which conveys its messages with a dose of horror and suspense.<br /><br />The characters and their development is really what makes Frankenstein special. I can see the suffering and anger on both Victor's and the creature's side. Victor is a good person who got swept up in his fervor for science without thinking about the consequences. After making the creature, he tries to move forward with his life, but his past follows him. The creature, on the other hand, is actually a sympathetic character. Far from the shuffling, silent monster seen in film, he exhibits great intelligence and is shown to be inherently good. After being consistently rejected and abused by man, he turns to violence and really only to mimic how people have always treated him. He only ever desired to be loved and accepted. I tend to side more with the monster because he was created and then immediately abandoned with no instruction on how to act or survive in the human world. I find the fact that Victor finds this acceptable and proceeds to further antagonize his creation reprehensible.<br /><br />I could probably go on and on about how Frankenstein is one of the best books ever written, so I'll stop here. This work is still relevant today and can both horrify and interest modern audiences. I think everyone should read this book at least once.which conveys its messages with a dose of horror and suspense.    The characters and their development is really what makes Frankenstein special. I can see the suffering and anger on both Victor's and the creature's side. Victor is a good person who got swept up in his fervor for science without thinking about the consequences. After making the creature, he tries to move forward with his life, but his past follows him. The creature, on the other hand, is actually a sympathetic character. Far from the shuffling, silent monster seen in film, he exhibits great intelligence and is shown to be inherently good. After being consistently rejected and abused by man, he turns to violence and really only to mimic how people have always treated him. He only ever desired to be loved and accepted. I tend to side more with the monster because he was created and then immediately abandoned with no instruction on how to act or survive in the human world. I find the fact that Victor finds this acceptable and proceeds to further antagonize his creation reprehensible.    I could probably go on and on about how Frankenstein is one of the best books ever written, so I'll stop here. This work is still relevant today and can both horrify and interest modern audiences. I think everyone should read this book at least once.

Franzen may be the darling of the publishing world but there are dozens of writers out there who write books that will have a lasting effect on their readers and this one won't.

0374158460|4.0|Friday October 22, 2010 >  \\"Freedom\\" by Jonathan Franzen.  New York:  Farrar,Straus and Giroux, 2010.  562 pages.    The novel is a fast-paced read, especially for this type of book. The characters are well-developed and do go through a semblance of development as the author uses several   techniques to permit the reader to co-analyze with the author as the novel progresses, a progression not necessarily in time but in purpose.  The major question we are asked to solve is exactly what is Mr.  Franzen's purpose in writing the book; and this is not so simple to discover.  After-all, it has all been done before in varied ways by different writers and the degree of relationship among the characters is certainly not revelatory.    So, in essence, the author is allowing the reader to fill-in his or her background perceptions to make the experience somewhat personal, but even in this, we find ourselves wondering why.  And the answer to this duality may be found simply in the basic fact that Franzen is an exceptional writer with myriad gifts which he uses to the fullest in the novel, but unfortunately, unless the reader has some depth in older classical writers, the novel seems to leave quite a lot to be desired.  It is easy to feel that upon completion of the book the reader ( although he or she no doubt experience enjoyment in the reading ), may wonder if Mr.  Franzen has been artfully taking his reader on a journey of personal discovery, and there are as many answers to this as there are pages in the novel, no doubt.

B0040YFR1Y|4.0|First off, every Predator fan should see this movie.  Was it better than the original?  No, but I think it was better than Predator 2 and light years beyond AVP.      I'll talk about the cast first.  A lot of people have problems with Adrian Brody playing the lead and if you're one of those people (whether you've seen the movie or not) I will to try to convince you otherwise.  Arnold was badass in the first film and it would be a mistake to try to recreate his character through someone else.  Getting an Arnold-esque lead would have just been competing (quite lamely) with the original.  Casting buff dudes to fight Predators has already been done, it was done right the first time, and it just doesn't need to be done again.  That said, take a look at Poncho.  That's basically Adrian Brody right there and he was equally respected and just as bad as the rest of them.  He was also the last one to die.  You don't need to be ripped to pieces to be a badass.  Case in point...watch the famous UFC fight between Royce Gracie and Ken Shamrock.  So, if you liked Poncho in the first movie, then I see no reason why you shouldn't like Brody in this one.    People have problems with Topher Grace too, but after seeing him in the first scene I knew he was going to be a win.    Alice Braga plays one of the strongest female characters I have ever seen.  She can whoop some ass.    I like the cast and I think it fits with the Predator mindset.  They want to hunt and they want a challenge.  They don't have a favorite body type, just favorite skulls and trophies.  You don't have to be ripped, you don't have to be male, you don't have to be good or bad, or have a certain personality, you can be anything as long as you have a weapon and some fight in you.    Bottom line is watch it.  If you're a fan you won't be disappointed.    [SPOILERS]    Some things I didn't like:  ------------------------------------------------  * Thought it wasn't quite believable that after they landed on the planet their first instinct would be to kill anyone they saw.  Royce didn't have that gut instinct, but I was wondering why Nikolai was going nuts with the chain gun.  He's supposed to be a hardened warrior, but it looks like he's panicking.  Seems like he would just try and figure out what was going on like Royce.  Just wasn't that believable for me.    * The scene where they're all firing into the jungle like in the first movie.  First movie did that, there was a good reason, and this time the scene just didn't carry as much weight.    * \\"Go on!!!  Do it!!!\\"  First movie did that and for a much better reason.  I know they're paying homage to the first, but there didn't seem like a good reason for him to say it at that point.    * Noland's arrival.  Ahhh no......reminds of that kid in Jurassic Park 3 who manages to find a way to survive with all the deadly dinosaurs...cheesy.  Arnold could barely survive a few days with one Pred and this guy manages to survive 10 years with many Preds, dog Preds, aliens, and who knows what?  Just not believable to me.  Not only that, but just like in JP3 how the kid's hair is way too nice and he just looks way too clean...Noland suffers the same thing.  His shirt and face are near spotless.  The only way they really salvaged his character was by making him crazy and wanting to kill all the others so he could take their stuff lol.  I started liking his character more at that point because after living on a planet like that for 10 years you probably would be a little crazy.    * Danny Trejo goes down way too easy.  I wanted to at least see him in a good fight.    Some things I liked:  --------------------------------------------  * Choice of cast.  Already stated, Alice Braga, perfect acting.  Don't see many females who can make badass look second nature, but Braga pulls it off flawlessly.  Adrian Brody, cool, new kind of hero for a Pred movie.  Walton Goggins (Inmate), funny as hell.  Topher Grace plays a good psychopath.  Overall the interaction between all the characters was better than I thought it would be.    * Stayed true to the original look of the Preds.      So, things I didn't like were kind of nitpicky, but there were a lot more things I did like about this movie.  Overall it's a good movie and worthy of the Predator franchise.

B003SWNRU2|4.0|I have to admit, I wasn't different from many others when I'd heard that Accept had regrouped with a new vocalist.  I kinda laughed it off in a way.  I mean, come on!  As solid a band as Accept is, Udo was just so unique a vocalist that you can't help associate him with the band's sound. I mean, it's like someone telling you that Mercyful Fate has regrouped without King Diamond and released a new album.  But then again I remember giving Iron Maiden a chance when Bruce left and Blaze stepped in(and God forbid I actually liked him!), and Judas Priest a chance when Rob left and Ripper joined(and I hated him).  Plus, Blood of the Nations had been getting remarkably good reviews across the board.  Hell, Accept deserved a chance too.<br />Well, with Blood of the Nations, Accept took all my skepticism and negative words and shoved them right down my throat!  They did record a good album!  A damn good one!  An....Acceptable one, if you will.  Granted, I don't feel it's quite as mind blowing as some reviewers have stated, but it far exceeds expectations.  Vocalist Mark Tornillo is very, very good and fitting to the band.  He's not simply trying to imitate Udo, which is good, but he does have that Udo-esque rasp with a touch of Jon Oliva and Eric Adams thrown in.  He's very welcome to my ears.<br />Musically, it's Accept alright...Accept of 2010.  This album wouldn't sound quite the same had it been recorded in the 80s, but there is no mistaking the Accept sound.  It's straight up, no B.S. heavy metal the way it should be.<br />If you too are skeptical about this one, have no worries.  In fact, check out the new video from the album, Teutonic Terror, and there you have it.<br />I should have never doubted Accept, they are indeed back.

The disk also includes the US and UK versions as well as the option to see the first part of the movie as it was originally intended - in black and white! 0312600844|5.0|This is Franzen's fourth novel, but only the second that I have read. I read The Corrections quite some time ago; however I picked up this novel not because of The Corrections (because, quite frankly, I don't remember too much about that novel) but because I've heard about this novel all over the place, from NPR to the Times.    Franzen begins by introducing us to his main characters - Walter and Patty Berglund - who are living in St. Paul, Minnesota in a run down part of town. They have purchased a home that can only be called a fixer upper. They seem to be a perfect couple - Walter works and is a sensitive husband to Patty, who stays at home, raises her children and makes staying at home her profession. And she does it well. The novel takes place in the years just following the September 11 attacks. Walter's son, Joey, is Patty's favorite and she becomes the classic helicopter parent to such an extent that she literally drives Joey away - he begins to sleep with the neighbor girl (Connie) and ends up living with her family because he can't stand to be in the same home as Patty.  Jessica is his sister. The story focusses on the questionable choices that each of Franzen's characters make.     I really enjoyed this book - it was a pleasure to read, even in my currently sleep deprived state. Franzen's prose makes it so easy to enjoy this book and to strive to read the entire 500 pages in one sitting.  The characters were well drawn and in depth.  It was a wonderful book to read.    Must add to your collection. I have an extra copy if anyone wants.  Please email me at mkowalewski[at]gmail[dot]com if you would like it. First one to respond gets it. Please include mailing address.

0553805371|5.0|It seems that the reviews for this book are all over the landscape; so I figured that unless I gave it one or 5 stars no-one would notice. I'm giving it 5 because there is little, from my perspective, to fault herein.    If, like most people, you have little or no interest in Quantum Mechanics, Cosmology, String Theory, Inflationary Universe, The Big Bang, Multiverses, and so on, then this is just the book for you! The authors make the best quick and accurate summary I've ever encountered and for that alone it is worth your time and money.    That aside one of the issues with this book seems to be that some folks (some of whom posted reviews before the book was released) seem to think that Hawking and Mlodinow were saying, or going to say, that modern physics 'proved' there was no god involved in the universe. While that is one way of looking at it another is to think about the publication of [[ASIN:B00087QUH2 On the origin of species by means of natural selection,: Or, The preservation of favoured races in the struggle for life]] by Charles Darwin. While this slim volume will not have anywhere near the the impact in my opinion, the 'punch line' is more or less the same: There is no need for recourse to a god to explain natural phenomenon, all you need to know to understand nature (including the universe) is explained, or will be explained, by science.    Now this conclusion has, predictably, generated a lot of heated comment from those who wanted to say that modern physics (especially Cosmology) somehow 'proved' the existence of a supernatural 'creator' or 'designer' or 'prime mover' or whatever. What Hawking and Mlodinow have done is shown that is an inappropriate conclusion.    Along the way they also dismiss the 'strong' interpretation of the so-called 'anthropic' principle.     One fly in the ointment here; the authors hook their star to M Theory. While that seems, at the moment, the best theory of EVERYTHING, there are detractors out there. When that get settled Hawking and Mlodinow will either have egg on their face or be crowing \\"I told you so!\\"     This is an easy read and even if your intent is to get peeved and disagree, it is worth you time.

0393072231|3.0|Liars Poker is one of my favorite books of all time so I was very excited to see another book delving deep into the US financial services industry. We hear so much about all of the people who are hurt by the subprime lending crisis, but until this book I literally knew nothing about the rare few who actually benefited from the crisis. Lewis goes into detail on a few characters who had the foresight and intelligence to see this crisis coming. Where this book falls a little short of Liars Poker is that Lewis has to spend a lot of time explaining the theory and structure of mortgage trading. Lewis is a very talented writer and is actually able to pull of this feat, but the reader still has to suffer through many very dry pages with very technical financial terminology used.<br /><br />I felt that the characters portrayed in The Big Short were not nearly as vivid or interesting as the characters portrayed in Liars Poker. This is likely because Lewis was writing about himself in Liars Poker and thus the reader benefited from that first hand knowledge and insight. While I enjoyed The Big Short it definitely does not compare to Liars Poker and certainly is not for those who are not well versed in finance.

B0045ZAQSM|5.0|If you're a fan of the German-born (of Turkish heritage) filmmaker, Fatih Akin, you will - like me - run not walk to see his latest creation, 'Soul Kitchen'.  Akin's masterpiece is, of course, the unsurpassed [[ASIN:B0009VND0E Head-On [Gegen die Wand]]] - one of the best five movies you'll ever see.  His [[ASIN:B001DB6J82 Edge of Heaven]] comes very close to repeating that magic.  Fans of Akin know that in those two works he delves deeply into Germany's rich and widening cultural and demographic ties with Turkey.  In fact, 'Edge of Heaven' starts in Turkey and takes us back and forth across the two countries.<br /><br />Here, Akin turns his storyline to another ethnic community deeply embedded into the fabric of German society: the Greeks.  Adam Bousdoukos (Akin's co-writer here - he had a bit role in 'Head-On') and Moritz Bleibtreu ([[ASIN:B0030Y1282 Baader Meinhof Complex (2pc) (Ws Sub)]]) play brothers Zinos and Illias Kazantsakis respectively.  Zinos is the entrepreneur in the process of re-inventing his erstwhile greasy spoon restaurant.  Illias is his ne'er-do-well brother who needs Zinos' support to make his terms of prison parole stick.<br /><br />Unlike his two previous films, Akin displays a flair for comedy here, though - Akin being Akin - even the laughs have an edge and manic verve that gives you a product a fair pace from light, breezy Rom-Com or Judd Apatow territory.  That fact is underscored when the inimitable Birol &Uuml;nel pops on to the screen as tempestuous chef, Shayn Weiss. &Uuml;nel's trademark intensity is seared into the eyeballs of anyone who's seen 'Head On.'  His portrayal of Cahit Tomruk in that film was nothing short of remarkable.  &Uuml;nel plays a supporting role here, but you can't take your eyes off of him any time he's on the screen.  In 'Soul Kitchen,' Chef Weiss' irascible nature hardly conceals his immense talents in the kitchen.<br /><br />Also good here are: Pheline Roggan as Zinos' long-time first girlfriend, Nadine; Anna Bederke as bartender/waitress/object of brothers' affection, Lucia; Wotan Wilke M&ouml;hring as over-the-top property developer/villain, Thomas Neumann; and - best of all - Catrin Striebeck as an imperious, exacting restaurant inspector. B003W5C0VW|5.0|In many ways \\"Ladies and Gentlemen\\" is the sequel to \\"Gimme Shelter\\", the classic Maysles brothers film document covering the Stones brilliant yet ill-fated 69 tour.  Here we are, less than 3 years later, the band roster still intact with Mick Taylor, and the Stones as dynamic as ever.  The music is flawless, the set-list is fresh and invigorating, and the added musical dimension, the horn section, launches the Stones down a new live-music direction that will last another 40 years and counting.    But something has changed in the 3 year span between Gimme Shelter and Ladies & Gentlemen.  Mick Jagger is still sneering, strutting and effortlessly controlling the vibe of the show, but he is now detached from the audience, no longer reacting with them or affected by them.  It is more of a \\"show\\" now than a communal experience, but it's still the greatest show on earth.    The camera work is a complete immersion into Mick Jagger, rarely cutting him out of a shot for more than a few seconds at a time.  The crowd is only there in sound, not a single audience shot can be found.  Jagger performs to a great black void interrupted only by the blinding cone-like spotlights following his every move.  The result is a feeling that we as viewers are sharing the stage with the greatest rock 'n roll band in the world.  We see every facial expression of each band member, we see the as yet unstrained rapport between Mick and Keith, and we even hear Mick's throaty moans underneath his harmonica playing.    The film is a combination of several shows, with several mysterious costume changes from Mick, and it ends too soon, leaving you wishing for more songs, but the end result is a perfect capture of the Stones at the end of their peak.  Within a few years Taylor would be gone and the Stones would evolve more and more into a shadowy parody of their glorious past.

B002ZG99CM|5.0|After Jaden Smith completed his role in The Pursuit of Happyness along side his mega-hit father Will Smith, it was assured that Jaden had the chops to join the family business. Jaden's mother is actress Jada Pinkett Smith (currently starring in TNT's \\"Hawthorne\\"). Both parents wanted their son's next major role to fit his abilities and they decided to produce an updated version of The Karate Kid, the smash teen hit in 1984. According to the Smith's, the vision of the film was not complete without securing Jackie Chan to play the role of the boy's mentor and trainer.    The Karate Kid, known internationally as The Kung Fu Kid (and perhaps a better title for the film) was shot mostly in China. The plot is identical to the 1984 version: boy moves to strange new town, boy get's bullied, boy get's trained to fight by wise, older martial arts expert, boy seeks revenge and learns many lessons along the way.    The Karate Kid, released this weekend , is indeed a film worth viewing even if you are especially fond of the original. It is difficult to remake a film that was as popular as The Karate Kid, but this film accomplishes the task and brings more sophistication to the story than the earlier film. Both of the film's stars do not disappoint. Jaden, believable as the new kid in a strange land, portrays vulnerability when needed and obviously trained for the fighting scenes.     Jackie Chan is spot on as the kung fu master and it is a treat to see another side of the actor who normally plays in more comedic films. The Smiths secured an all access pass to China, including a look at the Forbidden City. The cinematography and the film's score were enjoyable and impressive for a film catering to younger viewers and it is nicely cast with Taraji P. Henson portraying the mother and Wenwen Han playing the boy's first love interest.     The kung fu scenes are well done but may be too much for smaller children. All in all, this was the perfect movie to be released as school breaks for the summer. It's a film that the target audience will certainly enjoy and their parents will be taken back in time to their first \\"Karate Kid\\" memories and be glad that their children now have a film of their own.    For a look at reviews of films in the theaters not, click here: [...].

1592402038|5.0| TITLE  \\"Eats, Shoots & Leaves: The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation\\"     AUTHOR  Lynne Truss     REVIEWER     Josh Grossman, Colonel {r}, U.S. Army Medical Corps, M.D., F.A.C.P.     BOOK TYPE  soft cover     PAGES  209     ISBN  1-592-40303-8     COPYRIGHT  2003     PUBLISHER  Gotham Books      \\"We do not come as minding to content you,    Our true intent is. All for your delight we are not here.\\" {1}     When we turn over this text we are delighted to find the raison d'etre {2} for the title inscribed on the back thus. \\"A panda walks into a cafe`. He orders a sandwich, eats it, then draw a gun and fires two shots in the air. `Why?' asks the waiter, as the panda makes towards the exit. The panda produces a badly punctuated wildlife manual and tosses it over his shoulder. `I'm a panda,\\" he says at the door, `Look it up.' The waiter turns to the relevant entry and, sure enough, finds an explanation. `Panda. Large bear-like mammal, native to China. Eats, shoots and leaves.\\"   My having been introduced to punctuation in high school on an historic manual typewriter and my having learned reasonably well and reasonably early that punctuation may well be and often is the crux {3} of writing, I appreciate and recommend this text for the reference shelves of all of our City and Country Public Libraries and the reference shelves of all of our Colleges of Arts and Sciences. Certainly our high school English teachers may well consider the feasibility of keeping their own, personal copy on their desk for ready reference in their ongoing teaching of English Composition. Latin, {thus in the original, exactly as written}    Doctor Josh welcomes e-mails at <drjosh@embarqmail.com> from International Medical Graduates needing Mentoring/Tutoring in English as their Second Language who are preparing for their United States Medical Licensure Examination III   {U.S.M.L.E. B001IBIHQ4|5.0|To start this off, I am 18 years old, so my views may differ from some of the other reviewers out there. With that being said, I love anything that has to do with World War 2. I don't know why a lot of you are saying that it is better than Band of Brothers because in my opinion, I thoroughly enjoyed The Pacific more. It seemed like it had more character development which got you really attached to the characters and made it devastating when you had to see one of them die. Not only that, but having to see how they had changed when they got back. In the case of Eugene Sledge, at the beginning of the series he is full of life and just wants to go to war. At the end of the series he is completely changed, and that just broke my heart how he no longer seemed to care about much.          One other thing that is just amazing about this series is that it doesn't just concentrate on the war parts (the parts that I was originally watching for), but it also shows the characters relationships outside of the Marines. A good example of this was Robert Leckie who found happiness in Australia only to have it taken away.          There is no shortage of bravery and loyalty in this series either. John Basilone who received the Medal of Honor was then sent home to help sell war bonds. He first liked the attention, but soon he no longer liked everyone knowing him, and realized he may have made a mistake leaving his comrades during the war.         So if it were up to me, I would have every high school showing this to their students. Its a very emotional and heart touching series that shows just how cruel war is. And believe it or not, it even got me to further research the characters involved in the story and find moreinformation on all of this. Now imagine that, a series that can get an 18 year old to study American History. Good job Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg.

Although JavaScript is loosely typed and flexible, if you don't know the intention of each of its object and \\"type\\", your code will be a mess, and debugging on messy JavaScript code is painful. David Flanagan guides you to avoid that mess.    If you want to know more about the exact inner working (i.e. specification) of the built-in functions of a JavaScript implementation, then ECMA-262: ECMAScript Language Specification would be an excellent friend of this book. 0312600844|5.0|4 1/2 stars, actually.    This book will get you thinking, and talking, and wanting shake everyone of these people (including the country as a whole at times) as we watch these characters navigate around their notions of loyalty, desire, and disappointment.  Think of Anne Tyler's \\"The Amateur Marriage\\" set against the political landscape of post 9/11 America.    This is book about loyalty.  Loyalty to friends, to ideology, to Country, to our troops, to our community, to our Earth, and mostly, to our family.  Of course, no book could be about loyalty without also exploring the notions of betrayal, which Franzen's characters do in spades.    If you've read other reviews, there have been many comments about characters being \\"likable\\".  I'd like to just make a case for reading the ENTIRE book (I actually listened to the audio but will be getting a hard-copy to keep) before dismissing these characters.  Many of the character's motivations aren't explored until well after Patty's initial autobiography.    Also, note that who you \\"like\\" and who you sympathize with will change throughout the course of the book.  In the beginning, we don't particularly \\"like\\" Patty.  But we have to remember, we get to know Patty through her autobiography, which we know from the beginning of the book is being written as a form of therapy to work through her depression.  WE don't like Patty because PATTY doesn't like Patty.      As the POV changes, following Joey and Richard and Walter, none of these characters are nearly as sympathetic in their own stories as they are in Patty's.  Indeed, just as her self-loathing makes her character \\"unlikeable\\", the men in her life are much more sympathetic in her biography than they are when we actually get into their heads.      Also, though each of these characters make questionable moral choices, Franzen doesn't let any of them off the hook.  Each is punished, some cruelly, for their mistakes.  One character's fate is even reminiscent of characters found in the morality tales of Greek tragedies and Victorian literature.  Surely, Franzen's choices for his characters have stirred discussion and even controversy, as we watch the story unfold and discover who was able to crawl from the abyss and who never returns.    One issue I had with Franzen's disjointed narrative is that at times the transitions between one story/POV and the next can be jarring.  Franzen will take you to a climax, only to interject a long section of backstory into one of the character's histories.  As a way of prolonging the tension, it's somewhat effective, though at times the interruption is so abrupt that Franzen makes it too simple for the easily-distracted reader to get pulled out of the story.  Allowing the audio book to pull me through these transitions was a welcome benefit.    I'd like to also comment on the onslaught of 1-star reviews.  Anyone who is rates this book a 1, but finds it well-written or thought provoking, has had the extraordinary privilege of never actually reading a 1-star book (unintelligible, pedestrian writing, plot holes, etc).  Franzen's story may not be for everyone, but for avid readers of women's fiction in particular, it's a great opportunity to read the familiar, personal themes (fidelity vs. betrayal, love vs. sex) intertwined with grander ideas of ecology, economy, and politics.  You don't have to agree with the characters choices or ideas to find value in reading them.    Stick with it (listen to it if you have to) and you'll be rewarded.

As the hazy sunset cover photo suggests, these tracks feel a little more laid back, less anthemic/energetic and more \\"kick back and relax with a couple of beers.\\"

B003O2RQKI|5.0|Watching Lang Lang tackle Beethoven's Appassionata Sonata is like watching little David felling Goliath. This is true of his whole program which includes the Beethoven C Major Sonata Op.2, No.3, Albeniz's Iberia Book 1, Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7, and three Chopin encores: the Aolian Harp Etude, the Heroic Polonaise, and the Grande Valse Brilliante. 0596805888|5.0|Cooking for Geeks is one of the most fun books I have read in a long time. I don't get lost in the kitchen, but I'm certainly no great chef either. What this book does that is different from typical cookbooks is that instead of presenting a list of recipes, it talks about the science behind combining foods to create tasty dishes.     The book starts with an introduction to the kitchen; to tools, equipment, organization, and a way of thinking about them that is clear and easy to understand in the geek mindset. What does that mean? Those of us who call ourselves \\"geeks\\" have a certain way of looking at the world. We like to break things down to their components. We are not satisfied with only knowing what things do, but we want to understand how and why things work the way they do. That is what this book excels in teaching.    Chapter topics include science-based discussions of flavors, ingredients, temperatures, cooking time, and more. These things are directly related in the text to results. The information is presented in a manner that is easily understood by people used to changing one parameter over iterations of a process to discover what effect that one parameter has on the outcome. I like it.    This is not a reference book, which is what I consider most cooking related books to be. You don't pick it up and say, \\"Let's look for a nice dessert to make for when Aunt Mardella comes to visit.\\" Instead, you get something more valuable; the ability to look in your cupboard to see what you have, understand how those things could fit together to make something wonderful, and pull something together based on your understanding of the ingredients, processes and interactions available. That rocks! For this reason, the book receives a very high recommendation from me for anyone interested in learning about the science behind cooking (and there are some very interesting recipes included as well, so if that is what you are looking for, you won't be disappointed either).
0380799006|5.0|My husband and I read this book in 1989 after the birth of our second child.  We have since had 2 more children, two young adults and two teenagers now.  I am convinced the advice we read in this book was directly responsible for the relative peace we have enjoyed in our home.  All siblings are going to experience conflict, they learn valuable lessons about human interaction from these conflicts.  While our children did argue with one another, we implemented the advice from this book and did not get involved.  They were allowed to resolve the conflict without our intervention and thus learned valuable lessons about conflict resolution.  Our kids are great friends and make plans to be together.  They support one another in their various activities and we see very little jealously.  Our youngest is academically advanced and was asked to take the SAT's (at 13) the same year his older brother was to take them in his junior year of HS.  The older one was happy for his brother and said he hoped his younger brother scored higher than him so he could brag to his friends.  While I would love to take the credit for creating young adults who support one another so unselfishly, I have to give credit to the authors of this book for teaching us how to make that happen.   Read it, implement it, and live it.  You will not regret it!
